headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the PG&E 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'd like to turn it over to our host, Janet Loduca. Thank you, and enjoy your conference. You may proceed.
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the PG&E 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'd like to turn it over to our host, Janet Loduca. Thank you, and enjoy your conference. You may proceed.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Matt, and thanks to those of you on the phone for joining us. Before I turn it over to Tony Earley, I want to remind you that our discussion today will include forward-looking statements about our outlook for future financial results, which i
componenttext:
Thank you, Matt, and thanks to those of you on the phone for joining us. 
Before I turn it over to Tony Earley, I want to remind you that our discussion today will include forward-looking statements about our outlook for future financial results, which is based on assumptions, forecasts, expectations and information currently available to management. Some of the important factors that could affect the company's actual financial results are described on the second page of today's slide deck. We also encourage you to view the 2015 annual report that will be filed with the SEC later today and the discussion of the risk factors that appears there. 
With that, I'll hand it over to Tony.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Janet. Hello, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. 2015 was a really strong year for us, both operationally and financially. We continue to improve the safety and reliability of our gas and electric systems while delivering really s
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Janet. 
Hello, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. 
2015 was a really strong year for us, both operationally and financially. We continue to improve the safety and reliability of our gas and electric systems while delivering really solid financial results. 
Our earnings from operations in 2015 were $3.12 a share, which is slightly ahead of our guidance range. 
So I will spend a few minutes reviewing the operational and regulatory progress we made, and then I'm going to turn over to Jason Wells to review our financial results in more detail. 
We continue to believe that focusing on 3 key areas: positioning the company for a clean energy economy; delivering on customer expectations; and addressing outstanding issues, will provide the foundation for operational and financial success. 
So let me start with how we're positioning the company for a clean energy economy. PG&E continues to be a recognized leader in supporting the nation's goal around clean energy. In December, several PG&E team members and I joined Governor Brown for the global climate Summit in Paris. We participated in a number of events and panels where we shared the actions PG&E and California are taking to reduce carbon emissions, advanced clean energy technologies and spur economic growth. We were very proud to represent the California utility perspective at such a significant global forum. 
In 2015, nearly 30% of the PG&E's electric deliveries came from qualifying renewable resources. And even more meaningfully, nearly 60% of the energy that we delivered was carbon [indiscernible]. We know that as our energy mix continues to evolve, so do the needs of our electric grid. To deliver on California's low carbon future, we need to continue investing in a smarter, more resilient grid. And we need to ensure that rate structures are keeping up with these changes. Although we didn't make as much progress on rate reform last year as we would have liked, the commission has started to address the issues through flattening our residential tiers and moving towards mandatory time of use rates. And they have committed to review the rate structure again in 2019. We look forward to continuing to work with all the parties to develop the appropriate rate structure to meet our customers' changing needs. 
Turning to customer expectations. On the electric side of the business, last year, we delivered a seventh straight year of improved electric reliability. Our outage duration and frequency are now in the second quartile for the industry. We also delivered first quartile performance in both our 911 emergency response, our 911 emergency response and our wire down metrics. 
On the gas side of the business, we delivered top decile emergency response performance and broke ground on a new state-of-the-art gas training facility which we expect to open in 2017. We're also the first company in the United States to be certified in meeting the American Petroleum Institute's recommended practice 1173, which is a new standard related to pipeline safety and safety culture. We now have 3 external certifications recognizing the quality of our gas asset management and safety culture programs. We also continue to make progress towards resolving our outstanding issues. I'm pleased to report that we've closed out another one of the MTSB's recommendations by installing more than 200 automated and remote shutoff valves across our gas transmission system, and we're well on the way to completing the final recommendation to strength test nearly 1,000 miles of transmission pipe. In an important step forward, the Commission has officially closed out the San Bruno investigation. We've also completed hearings in the gas distribution record-keeping investigation and we look forward to resolution of that case this year. 
In the criminal proceeding, we received some positive rulings from the court late past year that narrowed the scope of the case. Most significantly, the court dismissed the government's alternative [indiscernible] claim based on alleged losses. The court is still considering whether to allow the government to proceed with an alternative fines act claim based on alleged gains. That determination will be made after the first phase of the trial where the government will have to prove that PG&E employees knowingly and willfully the law. We continue to believe that the evidence just does not support the charges. 
So to sum up. We had a really strong year in 2015 and we're committed to making additional progress in 2016. Before I turn it over to Jason, I want to reconfirm that we expect to address the dividend in 2016. I'm committed to doing that this year, although I don't have any specifics on timing for you yet. I'm excited to continue to work with Jason in his new role as CFO. He's been working closely with our finance and operational teams for a number of years, so he knows the company extremely well, and he provides  a wealth of experience and will be instrumental in helping this move forward. 
So Jason, welcome, and let me hand it over to you to discuss our financials.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony, and hello, everyone. I've enjoyed meeting many of you already and I look forward to meeting more of you this spring. I'll begin my remarks today by going through our Q4 and full year 2015 results, and then I'll provide some insights reg
componenttext:
Thank you, Tony, and hello, everyone. 
I've enjoyed meeting many of you already and I look forward to meeting more of you this spring. I'll begin my remarks today by going through our Q4 and full year 2015 results, and then I'll provide some insights regarding our 2016 outlook.
Slide 5 shows our 2015 results for Q4 and the full year. We had solid results in 2015, coming in slightly above our guidance range for the year due to some smaller positive miscellaneous items. 
Earnings from operations came in at $0.50 for the quarter and $3.12 for the year. GAAP earnings, including the items impacting comparability, are also shown here. All items impacting comparability came in within our guidance ranges. 
Pipeline-related expenses came in at $30 million pretax for the quarter and $103 million pretax for the year. 
Our legal and regulatory-related expenses were $14 million pretax for the quarter and $58 million pretax for the year. 
Fines and penalties were $137 million pretax for the quarter and $907 million for the year. The Q4 amount represents our estimate of the disallowed capital work coming out of the final San Bruno penalty decision, which we are accruing as we complete the work. 
Finally, our annual results show insurance recoveries of $49 million pretax. As we mentioned last quarter, we have now resolved all insurance claims related to San Bruno, recovering a total of $515 million. 
Slide 6 shows our quarter-over-quarter comparison from earnings from operations, up $0.53 in Q4 last year and $0.50 in Q4 this year. You've seen most of these drivers in previous quarters, so I'll cover them briefly. 
The biggest item, a decrease of $0.10, is associated with lower cost recovery in 2015 because we did not receive a decision in the gas transmission rate case during the year. So we incurred those expenses, but did not collect the associated revenues. 
Next, the nuclear refueling outage in the fourth quarter drove a $0.05 decrease over the same period last year. There was a $0.01 for regulatory and legal matters and $0.02 negative resulting from additional shares quarter-over-quarter. These negative drivers were partially offset by three positive items. First, we have $0.05 of growth in rate based earnings. Second, timing of taxes was also a small positive for the quarter and for the full year, as we've said, this item nets to zero. And finally, we had $0.09 of smaller miscellaneous items. For the full year, this line netted to $0.02 positive. More detail around the annual results is available on the appendix of today's slide deck. 
Moving to Slide 7. Today, we're introducing guidance for 2016 earnings from operations, up $3.65 to $3.85 per share. We're also providing ranges for items impacting comparability, which I'll come back to in a minute. 
First, I want to cover the assumptions we had in the guidance on Slide 8. Starting in the upper left corner, you'll see, we are assuming capital expenditures of roughly $5.6 billion this year. The breakdown by line of business is also included. Importantly, the gas transmission line assumes a range of $500 million to $700 million for the year and as you know, we're still waiting on a proposed decision on that rate case. This range includes about $300 million of safety-related capital expenditures that we estimate will be disallowed as part of the CPUC's penalty decision last year. In the upper right of the slide, you'll see that estimate of weighted average authorized rate base is about $32.6 billion for the year. Both the CapEx and rate base assumptions are consistent with ranges we previously provided. In the lower left, you'll see that we continue to assume a CPUC authorized equity ratio of 52% and a return on equity of 10.4%, which we now have certainty on through 2017. Finally, at the bottom right, we list some other factors we believe will affect 2016 earnings from operations. Our objective is to earn the authorized return on rate base for the enterprise as a whole, plus the net impact of the factors listed here. Many of these probably look familiar to you from 2015, so I'll cover them briefly. 
In terms of the gas transmission rate case, the first bullet highlights a key assumption underlying our guidance, which is that we will receive a reasonable outcome in the case this year. The second bullet is a reminder that we haven't sought cost recovery for certain corrosion control and strength testing work in the gas transmission rate case. We previously indicated these operating expenses should average a total of roughly $50 million annually over the 3-year rate case period, although the amount may vary year to year. 
Next is the tax benefits associated with our payers reduction. The net impact of this continues to be roughly $0.25 per share in 2016. 
The last item is incentive revenues for things like our customer energy efficiency programs. 
Finally, we continue to expect earnings on construction work in progress to be roughly offset by our below the line costs, which include advertising, share over contributions, some environmental costs and other items. 
One more point before I move to the next slide. Since we do not yet have a proposed decision in the gas transmission rate case, we do not expect a final to decision until at least the second quarter. So while the timing should not affect our annual earnings from operations in 2016, it will continue to have an impact on our cash flows and quarterly results as you saw last year.  In 2015, that impact was roughly $0.60. 
Now turning to Slide 9. The guidance for the items impacting comparability is $565 million to $665 million pretax. You can see that most of these categories are consistent with last year, pipeline-related expenses, legal and regulatory-related expenses and fines and penalties. We will also have a new positive category relating to the 2015 portion of revenues from the gas transmission rate case. We expect a final decision in the case this year with revenues retroactive to January 2015. This will be booking two years worth of revenues in 2016 will pull up the 2015 portion as an item impacting comparability once we get that final decision. 
The estimated range for pipeline-related expenses is $100 million to $150 million pretax. This component relates to clearing our pipeline rights-of-way. We are entering the fourth year of that program, which we've estimated will not exceed $500 million from its start in 2013 through its planned completion in 2017. The second component is legal and regulatory-related expenses, which we estimate to be between $25 million and $75 million pretax for the year. This component represents costs incurred in connection with enforcement, regulatory and litigation activities regarding natural gas matters and regulatory communications. The third component is potential fines and penalties, again, related to natural gas matters for regulatory communications. As you can see in the table at the bottom of the page, our 2016 guidance of $440 million pretax for fines and penalties, reflects our estimate of the remaining portion of the $850 million of safety-related spending that the commission disallowed as part of the San Bruno penalty decision last year. This range does not included any other potential fines or penalties. And last, we have the new positive item for 2015 gas transmission revenues, which will update after we receive a decision of that case. 
Turning to Slide 10. We assume equity issuance of $600 million to $800 million in 2016. That compares to equity issuance last year of right about $800 million. The 2016 range reflects a number of assumptions, including the timing and amount of revenues we will receive in the gas transmission rate case. 
Moving to Slides 11 and 12. We're providing updated CapEx and rate base ranges through 2019. 
First, on Slide 11. As I mentioned earlier, we're estimating about $5.6 billion in CapEx in 2016. This is a little higher than the $5.4 billion we spent in 2015. As you'll recall, [indiscernible] of our planned work last year to wildfire response. For 2017 through 2019, the $6.5 billion high end of the range is the same as you saw last quarter. As a reminder, the high end reflects the full request in our pending rate cases, which are the 2017 through 2019 General Rate Case, the 2015 through 2017 gas transmission rate case and the electric transmission TO17 rate case. And for the outer years of the gas and electric transmission rate cases where we have not yet filed a request, we've kept the high-end of the range flat with our current request. At the low end of the range, we simply assume that capital expenditures through 2019 stay flat with 2015 spending of $5.4 billion. 
Slide 12 shows our estimated rate base levels from 2016 through 2019. Next week, we will formally update our 2017 General Rate Case forecast to reflect the impact of the recent 5-year extension of bonus depreciation. The ranges shown here incorporate that update. Before I go into the numbers, I want to briefly discuss the impact of bonus depreciation on rate base and earnings per share. 
While bonus depreciation results in higher deferred taxes, which lowers rate base, it also reduces our equity needs. So while bonus depreciation have a noticeable impact on rate base, it has a small impact on earnings per share because of the lower equity needs. In 2016, bonus depreciation will not impact rate base because we are already in a net operating loss position through the end of the year. In fact, we now expect to be in an NOL at the enterprise level through 2019. However, we are also required to perform separate NOL calculations for each of our rate cases. As you know, we've had significant unrecovered costs in our gas transmission business, which has contributed to the enterprise-level NOL. But when we look at the lines of business covered by our General Rate Case, which are our electric and gas distribution and electric generation businesses, we do not expect to be in an NOL position beyond 2016. As a result, bonus depreciation will impact our rate base request in the GRC beginning in 2017. The cumulative impact of bonus depreciation in 2019 is a rate base reduction of approximately $1 billion at the low end of the range and about $1.5 billion at the high-end of the range compared to the guidance we provided in Q3. There is a smaller impact in 2017 and 2018. The majority of that relates to the 2017 through 2019 General Rate Case. A smaller amount of that reduction relates to the electric transmission assets, which are covered by our FERC transmission [indiscernible] rate case. The result is rate base grows at a compound annual growth rate of 5% to 7% from 2017 through 2019. And again, because bonus depreciation also reduces our equity needs, that mitigates the impact on future earnings per share. To help you with this, we're providing a simple rule of thumb to estimate the net impact on earnings per share from both the reduction and authorized rate base and the lower equity needs. On the margin, a $500 million reduction in authorized rate base equates to roughly $0.02 in earnings per share. 
One last note on CapEx and rate base before I open it up for questions. Remember that the high end of our CapEx range reflects only our currently filed rate cases, so there is some potential upside as we file future rate cases. 
Let me close by saying that I'm happy to be in the CFO role and I look forward to working with all of you. This is an exacting time for PG&E as we continue to see strong growth driven by California's policies and our focus on enhancing safety and reliability. 
With that, let's open up the lines for questions.

componenttext: Okay. So the equity issuance, kind of the $600 million baseline, the blue bar in the slides for '16, and then you have the shaded area for contingencies, is that $600 million become the ongoing run rate number as your expectation in this guidance or does that number come down?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not giving longer term equity guidance beyond 2016 but what I'll point to is the two main drivers of our equity needs, and that really has been our strong CapEx profile, which we're giving you ranges where you can make your own assumption. The secon
componenttext: We're not giving longer term equity guidance beyond 2016 but what I'll point to is the two main drivers of our equity needs, and that really has been our strong CapEx profile, which we're giving you ranges where you can make your own assumption. The second driver has been our need to finance our unrecovered costs. One of the biggest drivers in 2015 for that -- unrecovered costs is financing the remainder of the San Bruno penalty decision, which will be completed here in 2016. In the past, what we have said is that as a quick reminder, the -- we talked about the fact that our gas transmission right away program will extend through 2017. That was a 5-year program that we said will not exceed $500 million and will end in 2017. We also said that we've not -- we're not seeking approximately $50 million a year in certain costs as part of the gas transmission rate case. So that will extend into 2017. We need to make your assumptions around sort of those unrecovered factors but that's what I would principally concentrate on as the drivers for our longer-term equity needs.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, Tony, I know the board's going to consider the dividend as normal course, but what factors do you think you and the board are looking at to help find a place you're going to be comfortable to address the dividend? I think as we can kind
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, Tony, I know the board's going to consider the dividend as normal course, but what factors do you think you and the board are looking at to help find a place you're going to be comfortable to address the dividend? I think as we can kind of follow along, to think this will check off some boxes to get more comfortable?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan. I think there are a couple of things to think about. One is, we don't want this to be a one-off decision. So we want to make sure it's sustainable. Second, as you look at the changes that are going on in the utility business, we don't want to lo
componenttext: Yes, Dan. I think there are a couple of things to think about. One is, we don't want this to be a one-off decision. So we want to make sure it's sustainable. Second, as you look at the changes that are going on in the utility business, we don't want to look backward at what historical payouts have been, but we want to try and figure out what our companies -- what ranges our company's going to use in the future and we want -- we will be looking to then get ourselves in a comparable range. So we are trying to figure that out. And then, the third thing on timing is, obviously, we still have a lot of things going on and we want to make sure that we don't make the change at a time that would not be appropriate, given all the things that are going on. But I think [indiscernible] looking at all. I think the principal thing is making sure that our decision is sustainable.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, Tony, just on the payout ratio, it seems like the industry's dropped the payout ratio over the last five to 10 years. Is that suggesting that you think the current level is where dividend should be? Or are you going more to the [indiscernible
componenttext: And I guess, Tony, just on the payout ratio, it seems like the industry's dropped the payout ratio over the last five to 10 years. Is that suggesting that you think the current level is where dividend should be? Or are you going more to the [indiscernible] they do today, talked about payout ratio structurally higher than that 60% level?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you're right. The payout ratios have come down in years ago when I started this -- the business and 80% was considered way ought to be, obviously, has come down. And so we want to try and anticipate where things are going to be and what's ap
componenttext: Well, I think you're right. The payout ratios have come down in years ago when I started this -- the business and 80% was considered way ought to be, obviously, has come down. And so we want to try and anticipate where things are going to be and what's appropriate. So we'll be kind of sort that out and our board has asked for a number of different analysis. But clearly, we want to get ourselves to where we're comparable with the some of our fellow utilities that are out there.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: I was wondering if you could comment a little bit more about the impact of the distribution rate plan, ERP plan on possible increasing the CapEx forecast going forward and offsetting some of that [indiscernible] depreciation impact? As well, just wondering, how much spending are you planning on doing under the writer that you currently have in between rate case?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of questions there. As it relates to the DRP, I wouldn't necessarily look to that as a separate source of incremental capital. As we said in the past, our plans around modernizing our electric grid are incorporated in that 2017 through 2019 ra
componenttext: So a couple of questions there. As it relates to the DRP, I wouldn't necessarily look to that as a separate source of incremental capital. As we said in the past, our plans around modernizing our electric grid are incorporated in that 2017 through 2019 rate case and are reflected already in the CapEx that we filed. As it relates to the mechanism, something to consider there, that regulatory mechanism, which we call [indiscernible] has a really allowed us to spend additional capital previously to offset the extension of bonus. That was really intended to address situations where the extension occurred after a rate case decision. Not wanting to extend it before the decision as it is in this case is, that mechanism isn't necessarily [indiscernible] situation we have here.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And another question about time of use rates and the recent approval of net metering, the metering rules. Just wondering if is it possible that the time of use rates might actually make net metering less valuable to the solar players in your juri
componenttext: Got you. And another question about time of use rates and the recent approval of net metering, the metering rules. Just wondering if is it possible that the time of use rates might actually make net metering less valuable to the solar players in your jurisdiction? I'm just wondering what you think the impact of kind of use might have on solar growth in your jurisdiction?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Steve Malnight from regulatory affairs. Let me comment quickly on that. I do think there's several components of what we feel the rate structures need to move towards in the future. And time of use rates is one of them. So we were pleased to see i
componenttext: This is Steve Malnight from regulatory affairs. Let me comment quickly on that. I do think there's several components of what we feel the rate structures need to move towards in the future. And time of use rates is one of them. So we were pleased to see in the NEM decision that we'll be moving solar customers to time of use rates. It's not the silver bullet that solve all the problems and in total, that NEM decision, and we feel didn't really go far enough in addressing the issues that are caused by subsidization that happens with the NEM rate. But we'll continue to look at that decision. The commission did decide that they will be revisiting it in 2019 and I will just remind you, between now and 2019, we have a lot of changes that are happening in base rates in California with collapsing of the tiers and with the potential to move customers -- all customers to time of use rates. So we look forward to that conversation in 2019 as well.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ou next question comes from the line of Hugh Wynne with Bernstein.
componenttext: Ou next question comes from the line of Hugh Wynne with Bernstein.

Just wondering if you can give us a little more clarity as to whether the bigger items are on that if possible?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Hugh. As just a quick reminder, for the year, miscellaneous items, roughly about $0.02. So what I'll say is miscellaneous items generally have a number of factors, both timing and non-timing-related. A couple of the things that have driven t
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Hugh. As just a quick reminder, for the year, miscellaneous items, roughly about $0.02. So what I'll say is miscellaneous items generally have a number of factors, both timing and non-timing-related. A couple of the things that have driven the Q4 results were  higher gas transmission revenues as a result of the colder weather we experienced in the fourth quarter, as well as we experienced some favorable settlement and employee benefit costs during that quarter, which are reflected in those numbers. But again, it's -- these are really timing items and over the course of the year, they netted out to a small amount.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then on the item on the right, the $0.10 cost recovery item, those are basically increased GT&S costs that you have not been able to recover due to the delay in any revenue increase being granted in the case. There's nothing in that number for
componenttext: Great. And then on the item on the right, the $0.10 cost recovery item, those are basically increased GT&S costs that you have not been able to recover due to the delay in any revenue increase being granted in the case. There's nothing in that number for rate base growth and return on equity associated with your request in the case, right? That is excluded here.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That correct. That $0.10 really relates to our operating expenses for which we are not receiving recovery through the GT&S rate case because of the delay in the decision. But the full impact on a quarter basis is roughly $0.15 when you include the lack of
componenttext: That correct. That $0.10 really relates to our operating expenses for which we are not receiving recovery through the GT&S rate case because of the delay in the decision. But the full impact on a quarter basis is roughly $0.15 when you include the lack of return on rate base depreciation, et cetera. As I mentioned, it's a total of roughly $0.60 for the full year is the full impact of not having the GT&S decision.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: And then, Tony, I wonder if I could just ask you for a quick update on where we stand in the distribution safety records case, what we should be anticipating there, what downside risk there might be? And to the extent that there's new information that's worth bringing out on the federal indictment or the investigation into the bushfire, I'd appreciate that as well.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, we'll work through those and I may hand off some [indiscernible] detailed. The distribution records cases, it's in process. There's been testimony given in the case. So we got a consultant's report and [indiscernible] Steve just comment on exactly w
componenttext:
Okay, we'll work through those and I may hand off some [indiscernible] detailed. The distribution records cases, it's in process. There's been testimony given in the case. So we got a consultant's report and [indiscernible] Steve just comment on exactly where that is. With respect to the criminal case, the trial has been pushed back to the end of March. We continue to believe that there is no basis to conclude that any PG&E employee willfully violated the pipeline safety act. And we're proceeding on that basis. Obviously, when it goes to trial, it's going to be negative publicity, but we still firmly believe that we got a solid case they are going forward. And then, one other case.
ANALYST50
The bushfire?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Yes, the bushfire. Let me ask Geisha to comment on that.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: So as we previously reported, CAL FIRE's investigating, whether in fact [indiscernible] may contact with some of our powerlines in the vicinity and [indiscernible] of the ignition point. It's a very and detailed investigation. Its continuing and we haven't heard anything additional, so we really don't have any further updates at this point. Obviously, cooperating with them, providing them lots of information and we're  hopeful that we'll hear something soon. But our experience shows that this can take a while.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And just a quick follow-up on that. Tony, remind us of the maximum amount of the penalty that the government could now see on the federal indictment and whether if you have any guidance somewhere that is on the safety distribution rate case, I'd appreciate that.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me [indiscernible] part comment on where we are now on the penalty.
componenttext: Yes, let me [indiscernible] part comment on where we are now on the penalty.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the court issued an order late last year basically eliminating the loss base alternative fines act allegation. So it could've been up to $1.13 billion and that fine possibility has now been eliminated. So the other question that's under considerat
componenttext: Yes. So the court issued an order late last year basically eliminating the loss base alternative fines act allegation. So it could've been up to $1.13 billion and that fine possibility has now been eliminated. So the other question that's under consideration right now is whether or not the alternative fine act allegation based on gross gains can tend to be admitted and the court just recently deferred decision on that. And basically said that the court wants to see how the case comes in and if the company is convicted and if the alternative gains, evidence is not going to [indiscernible] complicate the trial, then the court will fight for [indiscernible] trial and consider that at the second phase.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: What's the max there?
componenttext: What's the max there?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's $562 million. So that's what's in deferred. But you have to also recall that the court dismissed 15 counts, so we're now down to 13 counts. And if you don't have the alternative fines act allegations that come in and if the government doesn't preva
componenttext: That's $562 million. So that's what's in deferred. But you have to also recall that the court dismissed 15 counts, so we're now down to 13 counts. And if you don't have the alternative fines act allegations that come in and if the government doesn't prevail on that, then each count has a fine of $500,000. So 13 counts would amount to $6.5 million.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And then, any similar guidance on the safety records case? Or is that not possible?
componenttext: Right. And then, any similar guidance on the safety records case? Or is that not possible?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me let st comment on that safety records case.
componenttext: Let me let st comment on that safety records case.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So distribution record, I'll [indiscernible] again. As Tony said, we concluded the hearing in January. I think we had a good and successful hearings in that case, so the case has now concluded. I would just highlight a few things. I think it's worth notin
componenttext: So distribution record, I'll [indiscernible] again. As Tony said, we concluded the hearing in January. I think we had a good and successful hearings in that case, so the case has now concluded. I would just highlight a few things. I think it's worth noting that even, I see these testimonies, they acknowledge that PG&E has made a lot of improvements in our distribution record keeping and commended us for some extensive use of external and external audits and we had the opportunity through the hearing to really comment about a number of the industry best practices that we've been implementing, including our efforts -- our multiyear efforts to consolidate and digitize gas distribution records, providing in the field with additional tools, including electronic maps and tablets and really multiple layers of safety protections in place than we do work in the field. So we thought that getting those things out was a successful conclusion to that case. The next steps, just to highlight for you, next week, we expect parties to file with -- they'll be filing open briefs next week, including SEB, so we'll see what that does. And I guess just the last reminder is that we're already  -- we're fined for the Carmel incident. So we'll see what comes out after the remains.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carmel was how big?
componenttext: Carmel was how big?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That fine was $10.8 million.
componenttext: That fine was $10.8 million.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Chris Turnure with JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Chris Turnure with JPMorgan.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow-up on the criminal trial question and maybe you guys could elaborate on the timing there and the different scenarios of what could play out. Are you saying that the gross gains fine could potentially be thrown out by the judge? Or
componenttext: I just wanted to follow-up on the criminal trial question and maybe you guys could elaborate on the timing there and the different scenarios of what could play out. Are you saying that the gross gains fine could potentially be thrown out by the judge? Or is it just best case scenario there, it would be kind of together with the current trial as opposed to separated out into a separate proceeding and kind of in all of those cases, what would we look at in terms of changes to the calendar?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So this is Hyun Park again. The court has not decided whether to admit the gross gains evidence. So that's still under consideration. So the trial is scheduled to start on the 22nd of March. And barring any further continuance, the parties have submi
componenttext: Yes. So this is Hyun Park again. The court has not decided whether to admit the gross gains evidence. So that's still under consideration. So the trial is scheduled to start on the 22nd of March. And barring any further continuance, the parties have submitted an estimate and the estimate that's been submitted is that it may take approximately 6 weeks. Four weeks for the prosecution and 2 weeks for the defense, but that, I think, are very rough estimate at this point.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tony. One other thing on the issue around the alternative fine. Because it's a criminal case, it has to be proven beyond a reasonable doubt. And I have trouble thinking how there would be any gain shown. In fact, the company sustained huge losses
componenttext: This is Tony. One other thing on the issue around the alternative fine. Because it's a criminal case, it has to be proven beyond a reasonable doubt. And I have trouble thinking how there would be any gain shown. In fact, the company sustained huge losses as a result of that. So the suggestion that they're going to be able to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the company had $500 million of gains resulting from San Bruno is hard for me to understand.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. They could still kind of throw out the idea that there was $550 million of gains, but still prove you guys guilty of having a deliberate attempt to -- for the law to achieve gains?
componenttext: Okay. They could still kind of throw out the idea that there was $550 million of gains, but still prove you guys guilty of having a deliberate attempt to -- for the law to achieve gains?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they have to prove that. That's the first step is that they would have to prove that there was a willful and deliberate violation of the laws. That somebody decided, I know what the law is, but I'm just going to violate it anyway. And then, you don'
componenttext: Well, they have to prove that. That's the first step is that they would have to prove that there was a willful and deliberate violation of the laws. That somebody decided, I know what the law is, but I'm just going to violate it anyway. And then, you don't even get to the alternative gains consideration unless you get that. And then, they would have to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the number was a number, whatever number they want to put.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got you. And then, what would be the potential final, I guess, jury decision point here in terms of one that would occur? And then is there still I guess a chance in this point in the process for a settlement to occur?
componenttext: Okay. Got you. And then, what would be the potential final, I guess, jury decision point here in terms of one that would occur? And then is there still I guess a chance in this point in the process for a settlement to occur?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me comment on the -- I mean, we're always open to a settlement if someone wants to make an offer. We've made efforts in the past that haven't gone anywhere, but we'd be open to it. But Hyun, comment on the timing [indiscernible].
componenttext: Let me comment on the -- I mean, we're always open to a settlement if someone wants to make an offer. We've made efforts in the past that haven't gone anywhere, but we'd be open to it. But Hyun, comment on the timing [indiscernible].

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I gave you the current estimate of how long the trial might take, and then, of course, it's a question of how long it takes for the jury to deliberate and reach a decision. And I can't to tell you how long that will take.
componenttext: So I gave you the current estimate of how long the trial might take, and then, of course, it's a question of how long it takes for the jury to deliberate and reach a decision. And I can't to tell you how long that will take.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: But given the late March started, you'd be looking at some time in probably the May time frame.
componenttext: But given the late March started, you'd be looking at some time in probably the May time frame.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, my second question relates to the GT&S [indiscernible] decision and final decision, whatever that may kind of finally come here. Is there a way that we can think about different buckets of CapEx that you have requested here? And any kind o
componenttext: Okay. And then, my second question relates to the GT&S [indiscernible] decision and final decision, whatever that may kind of finally come here. Is there a way that we can think about different buckets of CapEx that you have requested here? And any kind of color into how those could come out in terms of approval or disapproval? And just how to think about the various scenarios of the outcome here, even though you probably wouldn't want to forecast what actually happens?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I really think it's probably premature to forecast what the decision will look like before we have it in hand. What I will say though is that capital expenditures forecast for the year that we've included, the $700 million reflects what we filed in that c
componenttext: I really think it's probably premature to forecast what the decision will look like before we have it in hand. What I will say though is that capital expenditures forecast for the year that we've included, the $700 million reflects what we filed in that case. And so you'll have to make your own assumptions around where that case will ultimately end up.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Goldenberg with Luminous Management.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Goldenberg with Luminous Management.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to understand better [indiscernible] of bonus depreciation. So I understand that mathematically, how it works, but I also do know that you have a mechanism that you kind of have but  you can be applied for. Does this take that [indiscernible] tak
componenttext: I wanted to understand better [indiscernible] of bonus depreciation. So I understand that mathematically, how it works, but I also do know that you have a mechanism that you kind of have but  you can be applied for. Does this take that [indiscernible] take into consideration the fact that you may [indiscernible] get this mechanism or reinvest the CapEx? And you just don't have somewhere to invest to or you're just assuming you're not going to get it or are you being conservative and not just incorporating it in?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The ranges we provided do not reflect any incremental capital from that mechanism we've had in the past. I really think it's important to point out that, that regulatory mechanism, which has allowed us to spend that additional capital when bonus was exten
componenttext: The ranges we provided do not reflect any incremental capital from that mechanism we've had in the past. I really think it's important to point out that, that regulatory mechanism, which has allowed us to spend that additional capital when bonus was extended in the past, it was really intended to address those situations where that extension occurred after we've received a rate case decision. In this case, bonus was extended before we have a decision, so it's not necessarily applicable in this case.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you not [indiscernible] to apply for it?
componenttext: Are you not [indiscernible] to apply for it?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've requested the extension of that mechanism as part of our original 2017 GRC filing. But again, it really is intended to address situations where bonus was extended after we received a decision in the case.
componenttext: We've requested the extension of that mechanism as part of our original 2017 GRC filing. But again, it really is intended to address situations where bonus was extended after we received a decision in the case.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I do think you're unlikely to get the treatment again?
componenttext: So I do think you're unlikely to get the treatment again?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that's a fair assumption. It could be extended, but these bonuses already been extended for 5 years. I think that's a fair assumption.
componenttext: I would say that's a fair assumption. It could be extended, but these bonuses already been extended for 5 years. I think that's a fair assumption.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if you were to get this, how would do the numbers change?
componenttext: And if you were to get this, how would do the numbers change?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I really don't think the numbers change in this case. What I will point out though in the comment that I made, the high end of our ranges reflect what we currently file in our rate cases. And so just as a quick reminder, over this 2015 through 2019 period
componenttext: I really don't think the numbers change in this case. What I will point out though in the comment that I made, the high end of our ranges reflect what we currently file in our rate cases. And so just as a quick reminder, over this 2015 through 2019 period, our currently filed rate case for electric transmission assets is only through 2016, so we'll have to file an annual case for 2017, 2018 and 2019, as well, our GT&S case only covers up to 2017, so we will file an additional rate case covering the period of 2018 and 2019. There is the opportunity where we may spend additional capital -- request additional capital in those rate cases that are not reflected in these ranges here.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of with Citi Group.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of with Citi Group.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on Slide 12 where you talked about your updated rate base, and it seems like effectively, because you're mitigating the need to issue equity or reducing the need to issue equity, in your base case plant, [indiscernible] equity mean l
componenttext: Just a quick question on Slide 12 where you talked about your updated rate base, and it seems like effectively, because you're mitigating the need to issue equity or reducing the need to issue equity, in your base case plant, [indiscernible] equity mean literally in each of the years of '17, '18 and '19. Is that so? And secondly, is it possible that [indiscernible] bonus now, you probably don't need any equity in any one of those years? How should we think about that?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll come back to the two main drivers of our equity needs have really been our CapEx program. And so we provided ranges here. You're going to have to make your assumptions about where we fall out in that range and what that incremental equity will
componenttext: Well, I'll come back to the two main drivers of our equity needs have really been our CapEx program. And so we provided ranges here. You're going to have to make your assumptions about where we fall out in that range and what that incremental equity will be needed to fund those levels. The other driver of equity needs, as I've mentioned before, is our unrecovered costs. As I mentioned, the majority of the unrecovered costs that are driving our equity through 2016 really relate to the financing of the remaining penalty for the San Bruno penalty decision. We will complete the financing of that penalty this year in 2015, so you can make your assumption about what those unrecovered costs will be post 2016.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, secondly, on the retail rate perspective, as bonus depreciation reverses over time and rate base grows, is there any concern that there's a concern for retail rates going up in the '19 time frame and what that means for pushback in terms of furt
componenttext: And then, secondly, on the retail rate perspective, as bonus depreciation reverses over time and rate base grows, is there any concern that there's a concern for retail rates going up in the '19 time frame and what that means for pushback in terms of further CapEx spend?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're constantly focused on our affordability of our service, but there's a number of factors that are going to play out over the period of time with which bonus depreciation reverses, so I don't we can isolate that today as a driver or a concern about ou
componenttext: We're constantly focused on our affordability of our service, but there's a number of factors that are going to play out over the period of time with which bonus depreciation reverses, so I don't we can isolate that today as a driver or a concern about our rate levels.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Patterson with Glen Rock.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Patterson with Glen Rock.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a few quick ones. The community choice aggregation and net metering issues, are those sort of resolved now, one way or the other? Or do you expect further actions in those areas?
componenttext: Just a few quick ones. The community choice aggregation and net metering issues, are those sort of resolved now, one way or the other? Or do you expect further actions in those areas?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: As Steve and I mentioned earlier, net energy metering is not fully -- the commission issued a decision in what we call net energy metering 2.0, but 2019, they're going to take the issue up again. I mean, there's still this issue across subsidization. We t
componenttext: As Steve and I mentioned earlier, net energy metering is not fully -- the commission issued a decision in what we call net energy metering 2.0, but 2019, they're going to take the issue up again. I mean, there's still this issue across subsidization. We think there's still work to do to get the rate structure right, so we don't have one group of customers subsidizing, another, we're going to be continuing to work with, not only the commission, but all of the parties on this. So more to come on net energy metering. And so that's something we're going to be working on. The other part.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible]
componenttext: [indiscernible]

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: CCA, that gives local communities the right to aggregate. Now there's still PG&E customers. We deliver the energy to the customer. The energy costs are a pass-through, so we don't make money or lose money on CCA's. One of the frustrations that we have is
componenttext: CCA, that gives local communities the right to aggregate. Now there's still PG&E customers. We deliver the energy to the customer. The energy costs are a pass-through, so we don't make money or lose money on CCA's. One of the frustrations that we have is we want to make you the customers understand what they're getting when they go to a CCA. We want to make sure that from a cost standpoint and from a clean energy standpoint, we are very competitive and we think we are. But in the end, right now, it doesn't have an impact on our bottom line.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: [indiscernible] Net metering weren't either, right?

componenttext: [indiscernible].

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] choice aggregation. I think the commission acted on this or at least one of the issues related, whether or not that cost shifting is an issue, [indiscernible] net metering, that's been resolved. [indiscernible] what I'm saying?
componenttext: [indiscernible] choice aggregation. I think the commission acted on this or at least one of the issues related, whether or not that cost shifting is an issue, [indiscernible] net metering, that's been resolved. [indiscernible] what I'm saying?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Steve Malnight. I think you are referring to the PCIA proceeding that occurred last year in our [indiscernible] case and the commission set -- they finalized the [indiscernible] case in December and really, that sets our rates for this year.
componenttext: Yes. This is Steve Malnight. I think you are referring to the PCIA proceeding that occurred last year in our [indiscernible] case and the commission set -- they finalized the [indiscernible] case in December and really, that sets our rates for this year. They did announce they're going to have a workshop to look at the PCIA methodology going forward. And so it's a very complex methodology by which we calculate what are the costs that when customers leave, bundled customers have already procured on their behalf. And as a part of the CCA mechanism, they retained those costs when they go to CCA service. So we'll have a workshop on that here coming up very shortly actually, and we'll continue to work through that during the year, but there's not another formal proceeding that's been opened on that.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, as you guys are well aware, all those efforts for [indiscernible] forum, I mean, we've had legislation that's passed unanimously with [indiscernible] last year and it looks like it's again showing up, I think it just recently, some of the
componenttext: Okay. And then, as you guys are well aware, all those efforts for [indiscernible] forum, I mean, we've had legislation that's passed unanimously with [indiscernible] last year and it looks like it's again showing up, I think it just recently, some of the legislation and apparently, they don't overwrite those with the governor, but their validation of efforts, et cetera, I mean, just if you could comment a little bit on that or what opportunities or risks you see with these rather -- I don't know, it just seems that there's a big push legislatively, obviously, that passed unanimously for some form of reform and how we should think about that and how you guys are sort of handling it?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, in California, there are always lots of pieces of legislation and tied to handicap, which ones you're going to make it through the process, and which ones aren't. And quite honestly, we've kind of stayed out of that issue. [indiscernible] st
componenttext: Well, I mean, in California, there are always lots of pieces of legislation and tied to handicap, which ones you're going to make it through the process, and which ones aren't. And quite honestly, we've kind of stayed out of that issue. [indiscernible] structure the CPUC, we'll work with it. The bottom line though from a regulatory standpoint in California, we still have really good regulatory structures in place. And there's nothing that leads any of us to believe that, that fundamental positive regulatory structures that we have in California is going to change.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So these efforts or what have you, it's a lot of noise, but you don't see that as a threat to -- or risk to any potential change in that good constructive regulatory environment that you have. I don't mean to put words in your mouth, but am I unders
componenttext: Okay. So these efforts or what have you, it's a lot of noise, but you don't see that as a threat to -- or risk to any potential change in that good constructive regulatory environment that you have. I don't mean to put words in your mouth, but am I understanding you correctly?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we think from the utility standpoint, we'll work within whatever regulatory structure. A lot of the proposals around governance that the CPUC, but no one's proposing we change some of these very positive structures. And the trends that we've
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we think from the utility standpoint, we'll work within whatever regulatory structure. A lot of the proposals around governance that the CPUC, but no one's proposing we change some of these very positive structures. And the trends that we've had such as going to clean energy, which means we've got to modernize and make the grid more flexible, which means we got a lot of investments, which is driving our capital needs.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. And then just finally on the criminal case. I guess I'm a little bit confused. It seems like they're asking or they are seeking -- the way you described it is that they're [indiscernible] finding a willful deliberate deceit and I would
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And then just finally on the criminal case. I guess I'm a little bit confused. It seems like they're asking or they are seeking -- the way you described it is that they're [indiscernible] finding a willful deliberate deceit and I would assume that, that would be on the part of the individual. But it doesn't seem like they're charging in the individual, they're charging the company as a whole, if I understand it correctly. Is that unusual to be sort of saying, hey, sort of making a charge that there was a deliberate attempt to do something, but not actually charging the individuals with it? I guess I'm just a little bit confused about how that works or is that typical in these cases? I just don't know.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's something that we've obviously been pointing out to the court. The requirement is knowing and willful violations of the pipeline safety act regulation. And there's also an obstruction charge as well. And there is a theory out there called col
componenttext: Well, that's something that we've obviously been pointing out to the court. The requirement is knowing and willful violations of the pipeline safety act regulation. And there's also an obstruction charge as well. And there is a theory out there called collective knowledge, and we believe that's what the government is looking to. But as you know, corporations are entities and corporations as legal entities and don't commit actions. It's the individuals, right? So these are issues that are very much at play and they're [indiscernible] right now.

componenttext: For Tony, strategically, looking ahead,  a couple of years, we talked about clean energy, talked about next-generation grids, stuff, what's your appetite for investing outside of utility in some of those projects or whether it's secondary, third-party or even new guys, your sales correctly?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a really good question. And over the 4.5 years I've been here, the focus has been on really focusing on back to basics, getting the company running well, getting through the regulatory proceedings, things we talked about on this call. We do th
componenttext: Yes, that's a really good question. And over the 4.5 years I've been here, the focus has been on really focusing on back to basics, getting the company running well, getting through the regulatory proceedings, things we talked about on this call. We do think that there are opportunities. I will tell you, the affiliate rules here in California make that very difficult. In many states, you can have your experts in various areas, spend part of their time looking outside the utilities, [indiscernible] there their time to make sure that they're being -- their time is being charged at the right place. Whereas California, it's very difficult to use the expertise you've developed in the utility to work on things outside the utility. So you have to have a big enough opportunity to say, all right, I'm going to buy [indiscernible] instead of a whole separate organization to pursue these things. But that said, I don't think a week goes by where one of us on the team doesn't somebody coming in and having some ideas about how technology can improve this business. We actually look at them, generally incorporate them within the utility structure and be successful and help us there wouldn't help the bottom line necessarily, but might lower our cost to customers, which, in the long run, I think is a very positive thing. So we are looking at those opportunities because we really to believe that we are as far, if not farther along, then most of the utility in incorporating some of these technologies into the grid. I mean, as I said, we've crossed over 30% on renewables now and as for the 33% requirement by 2020, so where way ahead of the curve. Going to 50% renewables, we are confident that we can manage 50% renewable. Many of our colleagues in the industry are struggling with, how do you handle 10% or 15% renewables on your system? So we put in place the mechanisms and the technology to do it.
