headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the PG&E Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to introduce your host Ms. Janet Loduca of PG&E. Thank you, and enjoy your conference. You may speak, Ms. Lod
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the PG&E Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to introduce your host Ms. Janet Loduca of PG&E. Thank you, and enjoy your conference. You may speak, Ms. Loduca.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jacquie, and thanks to those of you on the phone for joining us this morning. Before I turn it over to Tony Earley, I want to remind you that our discussion today will include forward-looking statements about our outlook for future financial re
componenttext:
Thank you, Jacquie, and thanks to those of you on the phone for joining us this morning. Before I turn it over to Tony Earley, I want to remind you that our discussion today will include forward-looking statements about our outlook for future financial results which is based on assumptions, forecasts, expectations and information currently available to management. Some of the important factors that could affect the company's actual financial results are described on the second page of today's slide deck. We also encourage you to review our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q that will be filed with the SEC later today and a discussion of risk factors that appears there and in the 2015 annual report. 
With that, I'll hand it over to Tony.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well thank you, Janet, and good morning, everyone. I've got some opening remarks and then I'll turn it over to Jason to review our financial results for the quarter. We continue to believe that the 3 key focus areas shown on the Slide 3 are the foundati
componenttext:
Well thank you, Janet, and good morning, everyone. I've got some opening remarks and then I'll turn it over to Jason to review our financial results for the quarter. 
We continue to believe that the 3 key focus areas shown on the Slide 3 are the foundation for long-term operational and financial success. I'll also cover some of our near-term challenges later in my remarks, but I do want to touch on some of the fundamental drivers of growth first. So let me start with an update on how we're positioning ourselves for a clean energy economy and the growth that it will make possible. 
As you know California has some of the most ambitious greenhouse gas emissions reduction goals in the country and we're helping to stay to achieve those goals. First, as we plan for a 50% renewable portfolio standard, we're building additional flexibility into our contracts effectively respond to changing market conditions. We've also begun our second round of energy storage solicitations targeting nearly 600 megawatts of storage by 2024 to help manage intermittency of renewables. 
In March, we reached a settlement with many of the parties engage in our electric vehicle charging infrastructure proposal, which is critical to enable the levels of PV adoptions state is targeting over the next decade. We're hopeful the commission will approve this settlement later this summer. 
And finally, as the uses of our energy grid now grow and evolve, we continue to invest in new technologies and equipment to enable distributed energy resources and more actively engage with other stakeholders to shape future policies. 
Turning to customer expectations. Our recent J.D. Power survey results show that we made significant progress with our gas and electric business customers, with the largest year-over-year increase in customer satisfaction in almost a decade. These results reflect concerted efforts to improve the customer experience through ongoing safety and reliability investments. 
The El Niño storms this winter were good news and bad news. On the positive side, given all the of precipitation we've had, we expect Hydro production this year to be closer to normal compared with just 50% of normal last year. However, the increase storms also negatively impacted our electric reliability during the quarter. Nevertheless, we continue to show very strong emergency response performance on both the gas and electric sides of the business. And our teams are working to get our reliability back on track for the remainder of the year. We also continue to focus on reducing the number of third-party dig-ins on our gas lines. As you know, third-party dig-ins pose a significant public safety risk and are completely preventable through the free 811 call before you dig service. The significant steps we've taken to raise public awareness on this issue were recently recognized by the Common Ground Alliance and our efforts have resulted in industry-leading performance. 
In April, we announced that PG&E entered into an agreement with TransCanyon LLC, a joint venture between subsidiaries of Berkshire Hathaway Energy and Pinnacle West. the agreement with TransCanyon allows us to jointly pursue competitive electric transmission projects throughout the California ISO footprint. We look forward to leveraging our collective experience and resources to explore future opportunities. 
Last week, we had a development in the Butte fire when [indiscernible] fire issued its investigation reports. The [indiscernible] report concluded that the fire was caused by a tree, into contact with one of our alliance consistent with what had been reported in the press earlier. First, let me say that our thoughts and prayers continue to be with the victims and communities who suffered losses as a result of that fire and all of the devastating fires across California last summer. We also want to thank Cal fire and other first responders including our own for their heroic efforts in responding to all those fires. 
We continue to believe that we have one of the best vegetation management programs in the industry and disagree with the report's conclusion that our practices fell short. To give you a sense of that magnitude of our program, every year, our certified arborist and registered professional foresters monitor nearly 50 million trees across our service territory and remove more than 1 million trees each year. 
We use some of the most sophisticated technology that I have seen in my career for this program. Jason will review the financial impact of the Butte fire in just a minute. And finally, I want to provide a few regulatory and legal updates. I'll start with the 2015 gas transmission and storage rate case, which I know is top of mine for many of us. Although we had hoped to receive a proposed decision in the first quarter of this year, we are still waiting for that to be issued. As Jason will discuss, our quarterly financial results will continue to be impacted until we receive a final decision. 
In the 2017 General Rate Case, we are really gratified to receive a report from the safety enforcement division recognizing our risk management practices as industry-leading. The SED report found that PG&E's risk assessment approach provides greater transparency and successfully maps risk outcomes to requested expenditures meeting the commission's goal of moving safety to a fundamental consideration in the case. 
The SED report also acknowledged that the value of the third-party certifications -- they have acknowledged the value of the third-party certifications we received in our gas asset management programs. 
In April, we also received testimony from the other parties in the case which recommended reductions to our requests. Obviously, we disagree with those proposed reductions and we'll be filing our response later this month. 
In the gas distribution record keeping investigation, we receive penalty recommendations from both the safety and enforcement division and the city of Carmel. Fundamentally, we do not believe that any of the penalties are warranted in the case, however, our response noted that if the CPUC decides to issue a penalty, we believe it should not exceed $33.6 million and should be applied to its future spending rather than taking the form of a fine. 
At this point, the record is complete and we are awaiting a decision from the commission. I also want to provide a brief update on the criminal case. We continue to believe that the changes do not -- the charges do not have any merit. While we have acknowledged that we've made mistakes in the past, we simply haven't seen any evidence to indicate that PG&E employees knowingly and willfully violated the law. We're anxious to get the case on the way but just 2 weeks before the trial was scheduled to begin, the government finally provided us with more than 100,000 pages of documents that we've been requesting for more than a year. To ensure we could thoroughly review all of these material, we are compelled to ask the court for a delay. We're scheduled to go back before the court tomorrow to provide an update on our review of the documents and we hope to get a reasonable new trial date at that time. 
There are some things up. While we continue to work through some of the outstanding regulatory and legal issues, we are well positioned for growth as we support California's clean energy future. 
So with that, I'll hand it over to Jason to review the financials.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony, and good morning, everyone. I'll begin by covering the first quarter results and then quickly review the 2016 outlook. Slide 5 shows our results for the first quarter. Earnings from operations came in at $0.82. GAAP earnings including t
componenttext:
Thank you, Tony, and good morning, everyone. I'll begin by covering the first quarter results and then quickly review the 2016 outlook. 
Slide 5 shows our results for the first quarter. Earnings from operations came in at $0.82. GAAP earnings including the items impacting comparability were also shown here. The pretext number is for the items impacting comparability at the bottom of the page. Pipeline-related expenses came in at $22 million pretax in Q1. Our legal and regulatory-related expenses were $17 million pretax for the quarter, and fines and penalties were $87 million pretax. As a reminder, this amount represents our estimate of the disallowed capital work out of the final San Bruno penalty decision which we are accruing as we complete the work. 
Our results for the first quarter including new items impacting comparability for cost related to the Butte fire. Based on the Cal fire report, we've taken in charge for $381 million pretax for the first quarter. As background, California has a theory of inverse condemnation, under which utilities may be reliable for property damages without finding negligence when a powerline is involved in a fire. The charge was taken includes $350 million to reflect the low end of a range for property damage and an additional $31 million for other costs related to the fire. 
At this point, we are not able to estimate the upper end of the range. We do carry reliability insurance for claims like this, so we would expect to be able to recover a significant portion of those costs through insurance in the future. And we would show of the interim recoveries as an offsetting positive item impacting comparability in the future periods as they are recorded. 
Finally, it is important to note that the $381 million does not include an accrual for any fire suppression or personal injury images. Both of which would require a show in negligence. 
Slide 6 shows the quarter-over-quarter comparison from earnings from operations of $0.87 in Q1 of last year and $0.82 in Q1 of this year. The largest item relates to the timing of taxes during the quarter, which was $0.08 negative. GAAP accounting requires us to smooth the impact of taxes across the quarters even as income fluctuates. This is purely a timing item that would reverse by year-end. In the first quarter of 2015, we completed our disposition of the SolarCity shares. We did not have that item this quarter resulting in $0.03 negative. 
In issuing additional shares also resulted in $0.03 negative. These negative drivers were partially offset by growth in rate base earnings, which was $0.05 positive for the quarter. This item reflects assets covered by our General Rate Case and our electric transmission PR rate case. It does not include the gas transmission rate case since we do not yet have a decision. 
At this point, we would not expect a final decision on the first phase of the case until at least midyear. So while timing should not affect our annual earnings from operations in 2016, it will continue to have an impact on our cash flows and quarterly results as you saw last year. 
And finally, we have $0.04 [ph] of smaller positive miscellaneous items that impacted the quarter. Today, we are reaffirming our guidance for earnings from operations of $3.65 to $3.85 per share and that is shown on Slide 7. 
The underlying assumptions for earnings from operations remain the same as what we provided last quarter, so I'll just quickly cover the highlights. On Slide 8, we continue to assume capital expenditures of roughly $5.6 billion and a weighted average authorized rate base of about $32.6 billion for the year. 
On the bottom right, I want to reiterate a key assumption to our guidance which is that we receive a reasonable outcome in the Gas Transmission rate case this year. 
Turning to Slide 9. The guidance for the items impacting comparability has been updated to include the Butte fire-related costs. The other items impacting comparability are unchanged from last quarter. 
Our guidance for the year for the Butte fire-related cost reflects the Q1 charge of $381 million, which is the low end of the range for property damages, plus some other fire-related costs. As I mentioned, we are not able to estimate the high end of the range at this time. As shown at the bottom of the slides, the current range for items impacting comparability in 2016 is right about $1 billion. 
And as a reminder, this range excludes any potential future fines or penalties beyond our estimates of the disallowed capital and expense costs associated with the San Bruno penalty. 
On Slide 10, we continue to assume equity issuance of $600 million to $800 million in 2016. During the first quarter, we issued about $150 million in equity through our internal and integral programs. As a reminder, the range reflects a number of assumptions including the timing and amount of revenues we received in the Gas Transmission rate case. The charge for the Butte fire results in roughly $100 million in new equity needs this year, which puts us towards the high end of our range. 
And finally on Slide 11 and 12, we are reaffirming the CapEx and rate base ranges through 2019. So to conclude, we continue to have a strong growth profile supported by California's long-term policy objectives. We are confident on our ability to exit on our operational plans as we continue to work throughout outstanding regulatory and legal issues. 
With that, let's open up the lines for questions.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Stephen Byrd with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Stephen Byrd with Morgan Stanley.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to dig into the status of the efforts underway to create an integrated Western grid. Obviously, follow with interest your joint venture. But more broadly, it seems like there is a lot underway in terms of trying to move towards that overall goal
componenttext: I wanted to dig into the status of the efforts underway to create an integrated Western grid. Obviously, follow with interest your joint venture. But more broadly, it seems like there is a lot underway in terms of trying to move towards that overall goal and we can try to follow-up the procedural steps there. But at a high level, can you give us a sense of where that's headed? Is there any contentious issues or what sticking points in terms of trying to move forward towards the concept of a more integrated Western grid?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi Stephen, this is Geisha Williams. We're very supportive of the energy and balance market and also [indiscernible] efforts to really have a more regional larger footprint. There's a lot of discussions going on, good progress has been made already with t
componenttext: Hi Stephen, this is Geisha Williams. We're very supportive of the energy and balance market and also [indiscernible] efforts to really have a more regional larger footprint. There's a lot of discussions going on, good progress has been made already with the EIM or the energy imbalance market and a lot of discussions the current right now in terms of looking at beyond the energy imbalance market of what it would take to actually have a broader market, a broader area. We support it for lots of reasons, not the least of which is we believe that it will enable ISO to really dispatch lower-cost renewables, really take advantage of low diversity and supply diversity that have been really in existence in the Western area. So we're optimistic and very supportive of their efforts.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And; Geisha, any particulars of pushbacks or any it seems like there's a number of benefits to having a more integrated grid or are there any sort of negatives or issues that have been raised that could be potential sticking points?
componenttext: Great. And; Geisha, any particulars of pushbacks or any it seems like there's a number of benefits to having a more integrated grid or are there any sort of negatives or issues that have been raised that could be potential sticking points?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there could be. One of the issue is who governs this broad regional area. Right now, the Cal ISO is really focused on California and so the membership of the board is our California and is appointed by the governor of California. As we look at a b
componenttext: I think there could be. One of the issue is who governs this broad regional area. Right now, the Cal ISO is really focused on California and so the membership of the board is our California and is appointed by the governor of California. As we look at a broader market, it will be interesting to see what the makeup of that board would be, what the representation would be from other state and what the implications might therefore, be on California. One of the things that will create a bit of a sticking point will be that the rates of California is not increase as a result of a broader market. So these are going to be some of the issues that are going to have to be resolve.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And if I could shift gears quickly to energy storage. You've taken a lot of proactive steps in building that out. One sort of item of feedback we get is that obviously as cost drop, volumes in terms of installation could go out. At a high
componenttext: That's helpful. And if I could shift gears quickly to energy storage. You've taken a lot of proactive steps in building that out. One sort of item of feedback we get is that obviously as cost drop, volumes in terms of installation could go out. At a high level, could you speak to what you think will be necessary to have an even broader deployment storage, either sort of mild post levels in terms of overall cost that you would see or is this more of a gradual adoption kind of a plan in the state.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, California, again, is leading in this area and I think, of course, you know about the RFO storage, the storage mandate that we have in place. Where PG&E, we'll be putting in place 580 megawatts of storage between now and 2024. We had our first solic
componenttext: Well, California, again, is leading in this area and I think, of course, you know about the RFO storage, the storage mandate that we have in place. Where PG&E, we'll be putting in place 580 megawatts of storage between now and 2024. We had our first solicitation in December of 2014. We announced who the winners of that solicitation were this year and now we are awaiting approval. We're going to have yet another solicitation at the end of this year for an additional 120 megawatts. So we're seeing great participation from the storage market, which is very -- it's good years. We think that's it's an emerging technology, a lot of investment from many, many different countries around the world. And we are hopeful that just as we saw declining prices on distributed generation or solar panels that we will similarly see improve cost, if you will, on the storage side. But it's early days and I think the market is still evolving and we're watching it and hopeful that again, as more and more storage comes online that in fact, we'll see better pricing in the future.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And if you did see significant cost reductions in storage, could there be a step change upward in terms of the amount of storage that you ideally want to employ?
componenttext: Understood. And if you did see significant cost reductions in storage, could there be a step change upward in terms of the amount of storage that you ideally want to employ?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we believe the storage is a critical part of integrating renewables. So we're very active in the market looking at our own ownership as well as contracting with third parties. But again, it depends on the economics, it depends on what types of chang
componenttext: Well, we believe the storage is a critical part of integrating renewables. So we're very active in the market looking at our own ownership as well as contracting with third parties. But again, it depends on the economics, it depends on what types of changes we see in the future. Again, we're hopeful and are always in discussions with folks about what could potentially work. But again, it's like looking in a crystal ball. I really can't speculate on what prices might be and what our actions might be in relations to those prices.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Greg Gordon with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Greg Gordon with Evercore ISI.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know you've articulated that it's your aspiration to take some action to the dividend and give investors sort of a vision to what you see as the long-term sort of total return profile for the investment after we get through these last few milestones. Is
componenttext: I know you've articulated that it's your aspiration to take some action to the dividend and give investors sort of a vision to what you see as the long-term sort of total return profile for the investment after we get through these last few milestones. Is it fair for me or am I putting words in your mouth to say that GP and disgrace and the criminal proceeding are sort of the last 2 major issues we need to resolve before you feel comfortable articulating that outlook?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, first of all, we have made good progress internally on our discussions about the dividend. I feel good about it. Recall, at the last quarterly earnings report, I said it's my objective to be able to publicly state our policy this year. Obviously, yo
componenttext: Greg, first of all, we have made good progress internally on our discussions about the dividend. I feel good about it. Recall, at the last quarterly earnings report, I said it's my objective to be able to publicly state our policy this year. Obviously, you got to be sensitive to all the other things that are going on. So I wouldn't call think you mentioned as the things that have to get behind us, but they have to be in the right place in order to make a decision. I mean, I will tell you the Butte fire we're just in the early stages of analyzing what the impacts are and we got to figure that out. I don't see that it will in the long-run impact our ability at all. But you just have to be sensitive. You got to make sure you got all those things lined up when you make that announcement.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the Butte fire, I know you've increased your assumed equity issuance needs within the guidance range of course, as a function of that. But if you ultimately are covered by your insurance policies, is it actually necessary to equitize those -- reall
componenttext: And on the Butte fire, I know you've increased your assumed equity issuance needs within the guidance range of course, as a function of that. But if you ultimately are covered by your insurance policies, is it actually necessary to equitize those -- really necessary to equitize those cost?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Greg, it's Jason Wells. Over the long term, it would it be but there may be a timing difference between the recognition for the costs associated with the Butte fire and the receipt of the insurance proceeds. So over the long term, no, there will there
componenttext: Hi, Greg, it's Jason Wells. Over the long term, it would it be but there may be a timing difference between the recognition for the costs associated with the Butte fire and the receipt of the insurance proceeds. So over the long term, no, there will there be need to equitize those amounts but there may be a short-term financing need.

componenttext: Just follow-up on that topic. So will it would be fair to say that it's still vivid something that can be addressed in 2016?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then question on the criminal case. You mentioned the document dump and that you'll be kind of corresponding tomorrow I think to the court. Just curious if you and maybe we can get this tomorrow, but where there a lot of documents in there that
componenttext: Okay, and then question on the criminal case. You mentioned the document dump and that you'll be kind of corresponding tomorrow I think to the court. Just curious if you and maybe we can get this tomorrow, but where there a lot of documents in there that kind of what you say, better support your case? And obviously better -- it sounds like it supports your comment that you made that there's no evidence of any purposeful negligence.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of account, 1, the fact that we got 100,000 pages of documents dumped on us 2 weeks before the trial is quite remarkable. The hearing tomorrow is just to report on going through those docs. You that to go through them, somebody has got to re
componenttext: Just a couple of account, 1, the fact that we got 100,000 pages of documents dumped on us 2 weeks before the trial is quite remarkable. The hearing tomorrow is just to report on going through those docs. You that to go through them, somebody has got to read all the documents. They're not in -- they weren't given a form that you could to any automated reading of them. So somebody has got to put eyeballs on. It takes a while to do that. And yes, we are finding documents that are very helpful to our case.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes, this is Jason. We are still in the early stages of discovery and getting more information on the specific claims. With respect to the property damage though, I would say we have a good handle on the damages related to structures, but some of the other components are more complicated including damages to trees. As you can imagine, there are a lot of variables that go and quantify damages related to tree loss, including the number of trees that were burned over the 70,000 acres. The species and size of those trees, the pre-fire health of the trees, the post-fire tree value, other factors and so we're working through these issues and obviously provide an updated investment once we have a better information and are able to access those impacted parties. So that's what I would focus on from a property damage standpoint.

componenttextpreview: Well obviously that's our objective is to earn our allowed return going forward and we think we've done a lot of work both internally on managing our cost. We got a big push on affordability here. Obviously, we're going to invest what we think we need to
componenttext: Well obviously that's our objective is to earn our allowed return going forward and we think we've done a lot of work both internally on managing our cost. We got a big push on affordability here. Obviously, we're going to invest what we think we need to invest in the system. And I think given the approach in rate cases, we're very optimistic that the showings we've made in our rate cases will support getting a level of revenues that means that we'll have money to continue to make those investments. So there obviously going to be things that, but I think we're positioning ourselves well for the future.

componenttext: Just a general you're right, it's not just us. All of the cases have been delayed recently. We've had discussions about that. That's not helping Californians image from a regulatory a standpoint. We got lots of good policies in place but the policies aren't effective unless you can the decisions and based on. With that said I really do think this case is different. I mentioned some of the things that SED said about our filings. And also when you look at the bid ask range, it's not as big as it's been in the past and so we hope this can be moved along faster than in the past and maybe I'll let Steve Malnight comment.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Steve. Thank you, Tony. I do think a couple of things I agree with Tony. The case so far is moving along on schedule. I think we're optimistic about the case. The challenges do tend to come later in terms of timing. However, having said that,
componenttext: Yes, this is Steve. Thank you, Tony. I do think a couple of things I agree with Tony. The case so far is moving along on schedule. I think we're optimistic about the case. The challenges do tend to come later in terms of timing. However, having said that, in this case, we also did already receive the authorization to ensure that if the case is delayed, the revenues would be retroactive to the beginning of 2017, which is an important milestone that the commission has readily done in many of these cases. So the timing impact is somewhat muted because of that benefit.

componenttext: I know we've gone over this on past calls, but I wanted to just discuss the rate base and CapEx guidance for both this year and the next couple of years. Is there a chance that there could be lower CapEx than the bottom end of the range if all of your rate case decisions kind of come out at the lowest, I guess potential scenario that you guys have been anticipating?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I say it's really, really early to kind of presuppose any decision on this process. Just as a reminder, our CapEx and rate base ranges, what we provided here is essentially in the outer years. We stayed flat to what we were spending in 2015, which is I th
componenttext: I say it's really, really early to kind of presuppose any decision on this process. Just as a reminder, our CapEx and rate base ranges, what we provided here is essentially in the outer years. We stayed flat to what we were spending in 2015, which is I think is a reasonable assumption for the lower end of the range. And then on the upper end of the range reflects what we currently filed in our rate cases and where there's a period not covered by the rate case, we hold that upper range flat with the last rate case filing. So I do think it represents a reasonable range for CapEx and rate base over the next several years.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay, and then just to go back to the fire. Maybe you could give us a bit of historical context here and remind us of your last kind of major fire, where you had a liability there and how things kind of played out in terms of timing and amount of liability and insurance proceeds. And then am I to understand this special legal clause in the state of California as basically putting any utility on the hook to pay for trees and other property damage. Even if they're not negligent there? It seems kind of a lot there and obviously insurance proceeds do those cost of insurance and the premiums there get passes through the rate payers openly.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is Hyun Park, General Counsel. So you have a number of questions there. So I'll try to answer what I can recall. The first question was about our prior experience with fires and yes, we have had fires in the past. And for example, in 2013, we sett
componenttext: So this is Hyun Park, General Counsel. So you have a number of questions there. So I'll try to answer what I can recall. The first question was about our prior experience with fires and yes, we have had fires in the past. And for example, in 2013, we settled 2 fires, 2004 power fire and 2008 whiskey fire and it cost us $50.5 million to settle that -- those fire cases. In 2012, we spent approximately $30 million, settling the 2004 spreads and Sims fires. And 2009, we spent approximately $50 million to settle the 1999 fires. So those are the recent experience with fire cases. And yes, a question I think about inverse condemnation and basically, inverse condemnation is a doctrine that is based on the California Constitution. It's based on the takings clause of the California Constitution. And court said basically held that inverse condemnation may be found when 3 elements are satisfied. First, there has to be injury to private property. And second, the property damage was substantially cost. So there has to be substantial cost optimization and it does not matter whether there's fault or not. And thirdly, the damage had to be caused by a public improvement operating as deliberately designed constructed or maintained. So that's the language from the case law. And inverse condemnation has been applied to utility fire cases, where fires were caused by power lines. And court cases have basically describe the underlying purpose of the thumbprints is in getting to distribute throughout the community any loss inflicted upon an individual property owner by public improvement. And inverse condemnation allows recovery for property damage, prejudgment interest and attorneys fees.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think have 1 question about recoverability of our insurance costs. They are a component of our rate cases so we do file and seek recovery for the cost of various insurance programs.

componenttext: I just want to follow up on the previous questions. What's the past from here to reconcile the Butte fire? Do you guys go through the paperwork? You come up with a new target? Does it go to a court? Does it go to a district court? Where does it get resolved?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so to date, we have 32 complaints involving approximately 1,300 plaintiffs and their property insurers. So these cases have been coordinated in Sacramento Superior Court and of course, it's possible that more cases will be filed and right now what's
componenttext: Yes, so to date, we have 32 complaints involving approximately 1,300 plaintiffs and their property insurers. So these cases have been coordinated in Sacramento Superior Court and of course, it's possible that more cases will be filed and right now what's happening is the plaintiffs are starting to present to the utility claims seeking early resolution of the so-called preference cases and these are the cases that involve plaintiffs who had to do with their age or physical condition are not able to wait for the full trial process. So we're starting to engage in discussions with plaintiffs counsel about these preference cases and we have a case management conference in Sacramento Superior Court on May 24.

componenttext: Okay and then just lastly, Jason, if I hear it correctly, the fine recommended by CAL FIRE was $90 million but that's not included in the company's low-end of the rage right now, is that correct?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of things and that the first is the $90 million that CAL FIRE mentioned in its report was not fine. It was essentially, they are seeking recovery for their cost to respond to the fire. In order for us to be liable for this fire suppression cos
componenttext: So a couple of things and that the first is the $90 million that CAL FIRE mentioned in its report was not fine. It was essentially, they are seeking recovery for their cost to respond to the fire. In order for us to be liable for this fire suppression costs that were incurred by CAL FIRE, we'd have to be found liable for negligence. And we just don't see that as based on what we understand today, that we don't seem the possibility being found liable for negligence, as Geisha mentioned and as Tony mentioned, we have an industry leading management program. And so at this point, we have not accrued anything for this fire suppression costs.

componenttext: Yes, so -- this is Hyun Park again. At the earlier stages of the government's investigation of this case, the government insist that a certain of our current or former employee witnesses be represented by separate counsel other than the company counsel. And in situations like the 1 we're in, getting immunity by certain witnesses is actually fairly common and I don't think 1 should read too much into that. As part of our cooperation with the government, we agreed to have some of our employee witnesses be represented by separate counsel. And these witnesses lawyers negotiated an immunity and it's fairly routine and just being granted immunity does not mean that they're going to testify for or against anybody. I mean the bottom line is that they all have to be sworn into tell the truth.

componenttext: This is Tony. I might add that in the civil cases because remember we have investigation in the San Bruno but in the civil cases, most of these employees were deposed. headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start off. This is Tony. Obviously, affordability is one of the things that we focus on here. One of the goodness of things here in California as well some people save your rates are actually the total customer bill is below the national average. And
componenttext: I'll start off. This is Tony. Obviously, affordability is one of the things that we focus on here. One of the goodness of things here in California as well some people save your rates are actually the total customer bill is below the national average. And so while we're always sensitive, we still think that our products are overall affordable for the customer. One of California's challenges is in the rate structure that's been in place for a long-time really needs to be reformed because there are some groups of customers that are paying far more than they should and others probably paying less and we made some progress in improving that. We need to continue to make further progress on it.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you, great. And then secondly, just quickly, on M&A and strategic direction, both on the buy and sell-side, is there any view from your perspective on how you look at the landscape today given the consolidation that's happened in the space? How are yo
componenttext: Got you, great. And then secondly, just quickly, on M&A and strategic direction, both on the buy and sell-side, is there any view from your perspective on how you look at the landscape today given the consolidation that's happened in the space? How are you looking at the strategic box going forward I guess?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So obviously, we never comment on specifics of M&A. But just stepping back from an industry standpoint, I believe we'll continue to see if a fairly slow consolidation of the industry kind of goes in fits and starts. One of the interesting things is the co
componenttext: So obviously, we never comment on specifics of M&A. But just stepping back from an industry standpoint, I believe we'll continue to see if a fairly slow consolidation of the industry kind of goes in fits and starts. One of the interesting things is the consolidations recently the big consolidations have been creating combination companies, so gas and electric combining, of course, we're already there. We're a combination companies. Also California is different in many parts of the country, gas is viewed as the transition fuel from an environmental standpoint replacing coal. We have no coal on our system in California. So the long-term issues are a little bit different here in California.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Julien Dumoulin-Smith of UBS.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a lot has been asked and answered already but just following up here. First, just on the equity side of the equation. Obviously, Butte fire is not necessarily exclusively reflected. How do you think about equity needs '16 and more importantly onwards?
componenttext: So a lot has been asked and answered already but just following up here. First, just on the equity side of the equation. Obviously, Butte fire is not necessarily exclusively reflected. How do you think about equity needs '16 and more importantly onwards? You've laid out rate base, you've laid out CapEx, is there any good way to think about that generically?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I continue to focus on is sort of the 2 big drivers of our CapEx needs which are CapEx program that our unrecovered costs. For our CapEx guidance, we've provided a range that relates to our pending rate cases. I think there, you have to make an assum
componenttext: What I continue to focus on is sort of the 2 big drivers of our CapEx needs which are CapEx program that our unrecovered costs. For our CapEx guidance, we've provided a range that relates to our pending rate cases. I think there, you have to make an assumption of what we will receive in our rate cases and what our CapEx will be to inform equity needs related to CapEx. On the other side of unrecovered costs what I'll say is we expect to fully fund the San Bruno penalty in 2016. So that will go away after 2016 as a driver of equity needs. We also have our right-of-way program and gas rate case business which will continue through 2017 and as a quick reminder that's a $500 million program to be completed over 5 years ending in 2017. So that will continue into 2017. And then you have to make your assumptions around any additional unrecovered costs. But absent any new items, unrecovered costs should start to decrease in 17 and '18 and be much less of a driver of the ongoing equity needs for the business.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. And then continuing there you left it off when GT&S so may be curious can you elaborate a little bit more I know it's been out there for a bit what the rate impacts our by customer class. And perhaps, if you can comment to what extent is tha
componenttext: Got it, okay. And perhaps, if you can comment to what extent is that any potential limiting factor in getting the revolution here versus the just the conventional lag that we've seen before the CPUC and getting cases processed.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, this is Steve Malnight. I think that obviously this is a big case and it's been going on for some time. The rate impacts when you look at our original proposal, the rate impacts would be a monthly increase of about $5 a month or 12% for our customers.
componenttext: Hi, this is Steve Malnight. I think that obviously this is a big case and it's been going on for some time. The rate impacts when you look at our original proposal, the rate impacts would be a monthly increase of about $5 a month or 12% for our customers. That is an issue. I think that is in consideration and part of the discussion throughout this case. But more so it's really about what's the right work that needs to be done in the system and the right cost to do that. And I think in this case we've seen a substantial record built on why we believe the work we propose is the right work to get done. So we'll just have to see how that comes out on the proposed decision.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Hi Julien, this is Geisha. So we've been really successful within California in terms of competitive projects. But as we look at the broader market, we talked about earlier, broader Cal ISO footprint, we think an alliance agreement with TransCanyon makes sense. We think we have strength, they have strength and together, we can even be more competitive and successful.
